Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
What work's, my countrymen, in hand? where go you
With bats and clubs? The matter? speak, I pray you.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Why, masters, my good friends, mine honest neighbours,
Will you undo yourselves?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
I tell you, friends, most charitable care
Have the patricians of you. For your wants,
Your suffering in this dearth, you may as well
Strike at the heaven with your staves as lift them
Against the Roman state, whose course will on
The way it takes, cracking ten thousand curbs
Of more strong link asunder than can ever
Appear in your impediment. For the dearth,
The gods, not the patricians, make it, and
Your knees to them, not arms, must help. Alack,
You are transported by calamity
Thither where more attends you, and you slander
The helms o' the state, who care for you like fathers,
When you curse them as enemies.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Either you must
Confess yourselves wondrous malicious,
Or be accused of folly. I shall tell you
A pretty tale

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
There was a time when all the body's members
Rebell'd against the belly, thus accused it

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Sir, I shall tell you. With a kind of smile,
Which ne'er came from the lungs, but even thus--
For, look you, I may make the belly smile
As well as speak--it tauntingly replied
To the discontented members, the mutinous parts
That envied his receipt; even so most fitly
As you malign our senators for that
They are not such as you.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
What then?
'Fore me, this fellow speaks! What then? what then?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Well, what then?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
I will tell you
If you'll bestow a small--of what you have little--
Patience awhile, you'll hear the belly's answer.

Speaker: MENENIUS
MENENIUS
Sentence:
'Though all at once cannot
See what I do deliver out to each,
Yet I can make my audit up, that all
From me do back receive the flour of all,
And leave me but the bran.' What say you to't?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
The senators of Rome are this good belly,
And you the mutinous members; for examine
Their counsels and their cares, digest things rightly
Touching the weal o' the common, you shall find
No public benefit which you receive
But it proceeds or comes from them to you
And no way from yourselves. What do you think,
You, the great toe of this assembly?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
For that, being one o' the lowest, basest, poorest,
Of this most wise rebellion, thou go'st foremost

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
For corn at their own rates; whereof, they say,
The city is well stored.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Nay, these are almost thoroughly persuaded;
For though abundantly they lack discretion,
Yet are they passing cowardly. But, I beseech you,
What says the other troop?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: What is granted them?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: This is strange.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: You have fought together.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: It is your former promise.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: O, true-bred!

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Noble Marcius!

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Was ever man so proud as is this Marcius?

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: He has no equal.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: When we were chosen tribunes for the people,--

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Mark'd you his lip and eyes?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Nay. but his taunts.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Being moved, he will not spare to gird the gods.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Be-mock the modest moon.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: The present wars devour him

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Such a nature,
Tickled with good success, disdains the shadow
Which he treads on at noon

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Fame, at the which he aims,
In whom already he's well graced, can not
Better be held nor more attain'd than by
A place below the first

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Besides, if things go well,
Opinion that so sticks on Marcius shall
Of his demerits rob Cominius.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Come

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Let's hence, and hear
How the dispatch is made, and in what fashion,
More than his singularity, he goes
Upon this present action.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Lets along.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Breathe you, my friends

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
Though thou speak'st truth,
Methinks thou speak'st not well.
How long is't since?

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: 'Tis not a mile; briefly we heard their drums

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
Who's yonder,
That does appear as he were flay'd? O gods
He has the stamp of Marcius; and I have
Before-time seen him thus.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
The shepherd knows not thunder from a tabour
More than I know the sound of Marcius' tongue
From every meaner man.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
Ay, if you come not in the blood of others,
But mantled in your own.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
Flower of warriors,
How is it with Titus Lartius?

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
Where is that slave
Which told me they had beat you to your trenches?
Where is he? call him hither.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: But how prevail'd you?

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
Marcius,
We have at disadvantage fought and did
Retire to win our purpose.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
As I guess, Marcius,
Their bands i' the vaward are the Antiates,
Of their best trust; o'er them Aufidius,
Their very heart of hope.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
Though I could wish
You were conducted to a gentle bath
And balms applied to, you, yet dare I never
Deny your asking

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: March on, my fellows

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
If I should tell thee o'er this thy day's work,
Thou'ldst not believe thy deeds

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
You shall not be
The grave of your deserving; Rome must know
The value of her own

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
Should they not,
Well might they fester 'gainst ingratitude,
And tent themselves with death. Of all the horses,
Whereof we have ta'en good and good store, of all
The treasure in this field achieved and city,
We render you the tenth, to be ta'en forth,
Before the common distribution, at
Your only choice.

Speaker: COMINIUS
CORIOLANUS
COMINIUS
Sentence:
So, to our tent;
Where, ere we do repose us, we will write
To Rome of our success. You, Titus Lartius,
Must to Corioli back

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
The gods begin to mock me. I, that now
Refused most princely gifts, am bound to beg
Of my lord general.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Take't; 'tis yours. What is't?

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
I sometime lay here in Corioli
At a poor man's house; he used me kindly

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
O, well begg'd!
Were he the butcher of my son, he should
Be free as is the wind. Deliver him, Titus.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
By Jupiter! forgot.
I am weary; yea, my memory is tired.
Have we no wine here?

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Go we to our tent

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: The augurer tells me we shall have news to-night.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Good or bad?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Not according to the prayer of the people, for they
love not Marcius.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Nature teaches beasts to know their friends.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Pray you, who does the wolf love?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: The lamb.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Ay, to devour him; as the hungry plebeians would the
noble Marcius.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: He's a lamb indeed, that baes like a bear.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
He's a bear indeed, that lives like a lamb. You two
are old men

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
In what enormity is Marcius poor in, that you two
have not in abundance?

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: He's poor in no one fault, but stored with all.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Especially in pride.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: And topping all others in boasting.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: This is strange now

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Because you talk of pride now,--will you not be angry?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Why, 'tis no great matter; for a very little thief of
occasion will rob you of a great deal of patience

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: We do it not alone, sir.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
I know you can do very little alone; for your helps
are many, or else your actions would grow wondrous
single

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: What then, sir?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Why, then you should discover a brace of unmeriting,
proud, violent, testy magistrates, alias fools, as
any in Rome.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Menenius, you are known well enough too.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
I am known to be a humorous patrician, and one that
loves a cup of hot wine with not a drop of allaying
Tiber in't; said to be something imperfect in
favouring the first complaint; hasty and tinder-like
upon too trivial motion; one that converses more
with the buttock of the night than with the forehead
of the morning

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Come, sir, come, we know you well enough.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
You know neither me, yourselves nor any thing. You
are ambitious for poor knaves' caps and legs

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Come, come, you are well understood to be a
perfecter giber for the table than a necessary
bencher in the Capitol.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Our very priests must become mockers, if they shall
encounter such ridiculous subjects as you are. When
you speak best unto the purpose, it is not worth the
wagging of your beards; and your beards deserve not
so honourable a grave as to stuff a botcher's
cushion, or to be entombed in an ass's pack-
saddle. Yet you must be saying, Marcius is proud;
who in a cheap estimation, is worth predecessors
since Deucalion, though peradventure some of the
best of 'em were hereditary hangmen. God-den to
your worships

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Ha! Marcius coming home!

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Take my cap, Jupiter, and I thank thee. Hoo!
Marcius coming home!

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: I will make my very house reel tonight

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
A letter for me! it gives me an estate of seven
years' health; in which time I will make a lip at
the physician

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: So do I too, if it be not too much

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Has he disciplined Aufidius soundly?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: And 'twas time for him too, I'll warrant him that

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Wondrous! ay, I warrant you, and not without his
true purchasing.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
True! I'll be sworn they are true.
Where is he wounded?
God save your good worships! Marcius is coming
home

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
One i' the neck, and two i' the thigh,--there's
nine that I know.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Now it's twenty-seven

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: No more of this; it does offend my heart

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Look, sir, your mother!

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
O,
You have, I know, petition'd all the gods
For my prosperity!

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
My gracious silence, hail!
Wouldst thou have laugh'd had I come coffin'd home,
That weep'st to see me triumph? Ay, my dear,
Such eyes the widows in Corioli wear,
And mothers that lack sons.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Now, the gods crown thee!

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
And live you yet?
O my sweet lady, pardon.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
A hundred thousand welcomes. I could weep
And I could laugh, I am light and heavy. Welcome.
A curse begin at very root on's heart,
That is not glad to see thee! You are three
That Rome should dote on

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Ever right.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Menenius ever, ever.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Know, good mother,
I had rather be their servant in my way,
Than sway with them in theirs.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: On, to the Capitol!

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
All tongues speak of him, and the bleared sights
Are spectacled to see him

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
On the sudden,
I warrant him consul.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Then our office may,
During his power, go sleep.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
He cannot temperately transport his honours
From where he should begin and end, but will
Lose those he hath won.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: In that there's comfort.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Doubt not
The commoners, for whom we stand, but they
Upon their ancient malice will forget
With the least cause these his new honours, which
That he will give them make I as little question
As he is proud to do't.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
I heard him swear,
Were he to stand for consul, never would he
Appear i' the market-place nor on him put
The napless vesture of humility;
Nor showing, as the manner is, his wounds
To the people, beg their stinking breaths.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: 'Tis right.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: It was his word

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
I wish no better
Than have him hold that purpose and to put it
In execution.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: 'Tis most like he will.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
It shall be to him then as our good wills,
A sure destruction.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
So it must fall out
To him or our authorities. For an end,
We must suggest the people in what hatred
He still hath held them; that to's power he would
Have made them mules, silenced their pleaders and
Dispropertied their freedoms, holding them,
In human action and capacity,
Of no more soul nor fitness for the world
Than camels in the war, who have their provand
Only for bearing burdens, and sore blows
For sinking under them.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
This, as you say, suggested
At some time when his soaring insolence
Shall touch the people--which time shall not want,
If he be put upon 't; and that's as easy
As to set dogs on sheep--will be his fire
To kindle their dry stubble; and their blaze
Shall darken him for ever.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: What's the matter?

Speaker: BRUTUS
SICINIUS
Sentence: Have with you.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Having determined of the Volsces and
To send for Titus Lartius, it remains,
As the main point of this our after-meeting,
To gratify his noble service that
Hath thus stood for his country

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
We are convented
Upon a pleasing treaty, and have hearts
Inclinable to honour and advance
The theme of our assembly.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Which the rather
We shall be blest to do, if he remember
A kinder value of the people than
He hath hereto prized them at.

Speaker: MENENIUS
BRUTUS
MENENIUS
Sentence:
He loves your people
But tie him not to be their bedfellow.
Worthy Cominius, speak.
Nay, keep your place.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Your horror's pardon

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Sir, I hope
My words disbench'd you not.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: No, sir

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Pray now, sit down.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
I had rather have one scratch my head i' the sun
When the alarum were struck than idly sit
To hear my nothings monster'd.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Masters of the people,
Your multiplying spawn how can he flatter--
That's thousand to one good one--when you now see
He had rather venture all his limbs for honour
Than one on's ears to hear it? Proceed, Cominius.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: I shall lack voice

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Worthy man!

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
Our spoils he kick'd at,
And look'd upon things precious as they were
The common muck of the world

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: He's right noble

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
The senate, Coriolanus, are well pleased
To make thee consul.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
I do owe them still
My life and services.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
It then remains
That you do speak to the people.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
I do beseech you,
Let me o'erleap that custom, for I cannot
Put on the gown, stand naked and entreat them,
For my wounds' sake, to give their suffrage

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Sir, the people
Must have their voices; neither will they bate
One jot of ceremony.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Put them not to't

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
It is apart
That I shall blush in acting, and might well
Be taken from the people.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Mark you that?

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
To brag unto them, thus I did, and thus;
Show them the unaching scars which I should hide,
As if I had received them for the hire
Of their breath only!

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Do not stand upon't.
We recommend to you, tribunes of the people,
Our purpose to them

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: You see how he intends to use the people.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
May they perceive's intent! He will require them,
As if he did contemn what he requested
Should be in them to give.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Come, we'll inform them
Of our proceedings here

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: O sir, you are not right

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
What must I say?
'I Pray, sir'--Plague upon't! I cannot bring
My tongue to such a pace

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
O me, the gods!
You must not speak of that

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Think upon me! hang 'em!
I would they would forget me, like the virtues
Which our divines lose by 'em.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: You'll mar all

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Bid them wash their faces
And keep their teeth clean.
So, here comes a brace.
You know the cause, air, of my standing here.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Mine own desert.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Ay, but not mine own desire.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
No, sir,'twas never my desire yet to trouble the
poor with begging.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Well then, I pray, your price o' the consulship?

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Kindly! Sir, I pray, let me ha't

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
A match, sir. There's in all two worthy voices
begged. I have your alms

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your
voices that I may be consul, I have here the
customary gown.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Your enigma?

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
You should account me the more virtuous that I have
not been common in my love. I will, sir, flatter my
sworn brother, the people, to earn a dearer
estimation of them; 'tis a condition they account
gentle

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
I will not seal your knowledge with showing them. I
will make much of your voices, and so trouble you no further.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Most sweet voices!
Better it is to die, better to starve,
Than crave the hire which first we do deserve.
Why in this woolvish toge should I stand here,
To beg of Hob and Dick, that do appear,
Their needless vouches? Custom calls me to't

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Worthy voices!

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
You have stood your limitation; and the tribunes
Endue you with the people's voice

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Is this done?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: The custom of request you have discharged

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Where? at the senate-house?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: There, Coriolanus.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: May I change these garments?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: You may, sir.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
That I'll straight do; and, knowing myself again,
Repair to the senate-house.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: I'll keep you company. Will you along?

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: We stay here for the people.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Fare you well.
He has it now, and by his looks methink
'Tis warm at 's heart.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
With a proud heart he wore his humble weeds.
will you dismiss the people?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: How now, my masters! have you chose this man?

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: We pray the gods he may deserve your loves.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Why, so he did, I am sure.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Why either were you ignorant to see't,
Or, seeing it, of such childish friendliness
To yield your voices?

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Could you not have told him
As you were lesson'd, when he had no power,
But was a petty servant to the state,
He was your enemy, ever spake against
Your liberties and the charters that you bear
I' the body of the weal; and now, arriving
A place of potency and sway o' the state,
If he should still malignantly remain
Fast foe to the plebeii, your voices might
Be curses to yourselves? You should have said
That as his worthy deeds did claim no less
Than what he stood for, so his gracious nature
Would think upon you for your voices and
Translate his malice towards you into love,
Standing your friendly lord.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Thus to have said,
As you were fore-advised, had touch'd his spirit
And tried his inclination; from him pluck'd
Either his gracious promise, which you might,
As cause had call'd you up, have held him to
Or else it would have gall'd his surly nature,
Which easily endures not article
Tying him to aught; so putting him to rage,
You should have ta'en the advantage of his choler
And pass'd him unelected.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Did you perceive
He did solicit you in free contempt
When he did need your loves, and do you think
That his contempt shall not be bruising to you,
When he hath power to crush? Why, had your bodies
No heart among you? or had you tongues to cry
Against the rectorship of judgment?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Have you
Ere now denied the asker? and now again
Of him that did not ask, but mock, bestow
Your sued-for tongues?

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Get you hence instantly, and tell those friends,
They have chose a consul that will from them take
Their liberties; make them of no more voice
Than dogs that are as often beat for barking
As therefore kept to do so.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Let them assemble,
And on a safer judgment all revoke
Your ignorant election; enforce his pride,
And his old hate unto you; besides, forget not
With what contempt he wore the humble weed,
How in his suit he scorn'd you; but your loves,
Thinking upon his services, took from you
The apprehension of his present portance,
Which most gibingly, ungravely, he did fashion
After the inveterate hate he bears you.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Lay
A fault on us, your tribunes; that we laboured,
No impediment between, but that you must
Cast your election on him.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Say, you chose him
More after our commandment than as guided
By your own true affections, and that your minds,
Preoccupied with what you rather must do
Than what you should, made you against the grain
To voice him consul

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Ay, spare us not. Say we read lectures to you.
How youngly he began to serve his country,
How long continued, and what stock he springs of,
The noble house o' the Marcians, from whence came
That Ancus Marcius, Numa's daughter's son,
Who, after great Hostilius, here was king;
Of the same house Publius and Quintus were,
That our beat water brought by conduits hither;
And  
Twice being  
Was his great ancestor.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
One thus descended,
That hath beside well in his person wrought
To be set high in place, we did commend
To your remembrances

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Say, you ne'er had done't--
Harp on that still--but by our putting on;
And presently, when you have drawn your number,
Repair to the Capitol.

Speaker: BRUTUS
SICINIUS
Sentence: To the Capitol, come

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Tullus Aufidius then had made new head?

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
So then the Volsces stand but as at first,
Ready, when time shall prompt them, to make road.
Upon's again.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
They are worn, lord consul, so,
That we shall hardly in our ages see
Their banners wave again.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Saw you Aufidius?

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Spoke he of me?

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: How? what?

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: At Antium lives he?

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
I wish I had a cause to seek him there,
To oppose his hatred fully. Welcome home.
Behold, these are the tribunes of the people,
The tongues o' the common mouth

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Pass no further.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Ha! what is that?

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: It will be dangerous to go on

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: What makes this change?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: The matter?

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Hath he not pass'd the noble and the common?

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Cominius, no.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Have I had children's voices?

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: The people are incensed against him.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Stop,
Or all will fall in broil.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Are these your herd?
Must these have voices, that can yield them now
And straight disclaim their tongues? What are
your offices?
You being their mouths, why rule you not their teeth?
Have you not set them on?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Be calm, be calm.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
It is a purposed thing, and grows by plot,
To curb the will of the nobility

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Call't not a plot

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Why, this was known before.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Not to them all.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Have you inform'd them sithence?

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: How! I inform them!

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: You are like to do such business.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Not unlike,
Each way, to better yours.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Why then should I be consul? By yond clouds,
Let me deserve so ill as you, and make me
Your fellow tribune.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
You show too much of that
For which the people stir

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Let's be calm.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
The people are abused; set on. This paltering
Becomes not Rome, nor has Coriolanus
Deserved this so dishonour'd rub, laid falsely
I' the plain way of his merit.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Tell me of corn!
This was my speech, and I will speak't again--

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Not now, not now.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Now, as I live, I will. My nobler friends,
I crave their pardons

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Well, no more.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
How! no more!
As for my country I have shed my blood,
Not fearing outward force, so shall my lungs
Coin words till their decay against those measles,
Which we disdain should tatter us, yet sought
The very way to catch them.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
You speak o' the people,
As if you were a god to punish, not
A man of their infirmity.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
'Twere well
We let the people know't.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: What, what? his choler?

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Choler!
Were I as patient as the midnight sleep,
By Jove, 'twould be my mind!

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
It is a mind
That shall remain a poison where it is,
Not poison any further.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Shall remain!
Hear you this Triton of the minnows? mark you
His absolute 'shall'?

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: 'Twas from the canon.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
'Shall'!
O good but most unwise patricians! why,
You grave but reckless senators, have you thus
Given Hydra here to choose an officer,
That with his peremptory 'shall,' being but
The horn and noise o' the monster's, wants not spirit
To say he'll turn your current in a ditch,
And make your channel his? If he have power
Then vail your ignorance; if none, awake
Your dangerous lenity. If you are learn'd,
Be not as common fools; if you are not,
Let them have cushions by you. You are plebeians,
If they be senators

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Well, on to the market-place.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Whoever gave that counsel, to give forth
The corn o' the storehouse gratis, as 'twas used
Sometime in Greece,--

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Well, well, no more of that.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Though there the people had more absolute power,
I say, they nourish'd disobedience, fed
The ruin of the state.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Why, shall the people give
One that speaks thus their voice?

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
I'll give my reasons,
More worthier than their voices. They know the corn
Was not our recompense, resting well assured
That ne'er did service for't

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Come, enough.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Enough, with over-measure.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: No, take more

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Has said enough.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Has spoken like a traitor, and shall answer
As traitors do.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Thou wretch, despite o'erwhelm thee!
What should the people do with these bald tribunes?
On whom depending, their obedience fails
To the greater bench

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Manifest treason!

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: This a consul? no.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
The aediles, ho!
Let him be apprehended.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Go, call the people

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Hence, old goat!

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Aged sir, hands off.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Hence, rotten thing! or I shall shake thy bones
Out of thy garments.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Help, ye citizens!

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: On both sides more respect.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Here's he that would take from you all your power.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Seize him, AEdiles!

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
What is about to be? I am out of breath;
Confusion's near; I cannot speak. You, tribunes
To the people! Coriolanus, patience!
Speak, good Sicinius.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Hear me, people; peace!

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: You are at point to lose your liberties

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Fie, fie, fie!
This is the way to kindle, not to quench.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: What is the city but the people?

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
By the consent of all, we were establish'd
The people's magistrates.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: And so are like to do.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
That is the way to lay the city flat;
To bring the roof to the foundation,
And bury all, which yet distinctly ranges,
In heaps and piles of ruin.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: This deserves death.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Or let us stand to our authority,
Or let us lose it. We do here pronounce,
Upon the part o' the people, in whose power
We were elected theirs, Marcius is worthy
Of present death.

Speaker: SICINIUS
BRUTUS
Sentence: AEdiles, seize him!

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Hear me one word;
Beseech you, tribunes, hear me but a word.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Sir, those cold ways,
That seem like prudent helps, are very poisonous
Where the disease is violent. Lay hands upon him,
And bear him to the rock.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
No, I'll die here.
There's some among you have beheld me fighting

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Down with that sword! Tribunes, withdraw awhile.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Lay hands upon him.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
Help Marcius, help,
You that be noble; help him, young and old!

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Go, get you to your house; be gone, away!
All will be naught else.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
Stand fast;
We have as many friends as enemies.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Sham it be put to that?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
For 'tis a sore upon us,
You cannot tent yourself

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Come, sir, along with us.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
I would they were barbarians--as they are,
Though in Rome litter'd--not Romans--as they are not,
Though calved i' the porch o' the Capitol--

Speaker: MENENIUS
CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
On fair ground
I could beat forty of them.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
I could myself
Take up a brace o' the best of them; yea, the
two tribunes

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Pray you, be gone

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Nay, come away.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: His nature is too noble for the world

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
I would they were in Tiber! What the vengeance!
Could he not speak 'em fair?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Where is this viper
That would depopulate the city and
Be every man himself?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: You worthy tribunes,--

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
He shall be thrown down the Tarpeian rock
With rigorous hands

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Sir, sir,--

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Peace!

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Do not cry havoc, where you should but hunt
With modest warrant.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Sir, how comes't that you
Have holp to make this rescue?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Hear me speak

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Consul! what consul?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: The consul Coriolanus.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: He consul!

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
If, by the tribunes' leave, and yours, good people,
I may be heard, I would crave a word or two;
The which shall turn you to no further harm
Than so much loss of time.

Speaker: SICINIUS
MENENIUS
Sentence:
Now the good gods forbid
That our renowned Rome, whose gratitude
Towards her deserved children is enroll'd
In Jove's own book, like an unnatural dam
Should now eat up her own!

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: He's a disease that must be cut away.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
O, he's a limb that has but a disease;
Mortal, to cut it off; to cure it, easy.
What has he done to Rome that's worthy death?
Killing our enemies, the blood he hath lost--
Which, I dare vouch, is more than that he hath,
By many an ounce--he dropp'd it for his country;
And what is left, to lose it by his country,
Were to us all, that do't and suffer it,
A brand to the end o' the world.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: This is clean kam.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Merely awry

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
The service of the foot
Being once gangrened, is not then respected
For what before it was.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
We'll hear no more.
Pursue him to his house, and pluck him thence

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
One word more, one word.
This tiger-footed rage, when it shall find
The harm of unscann'd swiftness, will too late
Tie leaden pounds to's heels. Proceed by process;
Lest parties, as he is beloved, break out,
And sack great Rome with Romans.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: If it were so,--

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
What do ye talk?
Have we not had a taste of his obedience?
Our aediles smote? ourselves resisted? Come.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Consider this

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Noble Menenius,
Be you then as the people's officer.
Masters, lay down your weapons.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Go not home.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Meet on the market-place. We'll attend you there

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
I'll bring him to you.
Let me desire your company

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Let them puff all about mine ears, present me
Death on the wheel or at wild horses' heels,
Or pile ten hills on the Tarpeian rock,
That the precipitation might down stretch
Below the beam of sight, yet will I still
Be thus to them.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
I muse my mother
Does not approve me further, who was wont
To call them woollen vassals, things created
To buy and sell with groats, to show bare heads
In congregations, to yawn, be still and wonder,
When one but of my ordinance stood up
To speak of peace or war.
I talk of you

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Let go.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Let them hang.

Speaker: MENENIUS
MENENIUS
Sentence:
Well said, noble woman?
Before he should thus stoop to the herd, but that
The violent fit o' the time craves it as physic
For the whole state, I would put mine armour on,
Which I can scarcely bear.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: What must I do?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Return to the tribunes.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Well, what then? what then?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Repent what you have spoke.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
For them! I cannot do it to the gods;
Must I then do't to them?

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Tush, tush!

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: A good demand.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Why force you this?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Noble lady!
Come, go with us; speak fair

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
This but done,
Even as she speaks, why, their hearts were yours;
For they have pardons, being ask'd, as free
As words to little purpose.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
I have been i' the market-place; and, sir,'tis fit
You make strong party, or defend yourself
By calmness or by absence

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Only fair speech.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
I think 'twill serve, if he
Can thereto frame his spirit.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Must I go show them my unbarbed sconce?
Must I with base tongue give my noble heart
A lie that it must bear? Well, I will do't

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Come, come, we'll prompt you.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Well, I must do't

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Pray, be content

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Away! the tribunes do attend you

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: The word is 'mildly.' Pray you, let us go

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Ay, but mildly.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Well, mildly be it then. Mildly!

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
In this point charge him home, that he affects
Tyrannical power

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: How accompanied?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Have you a catalogue
Of all the voices that we have procured
Set down by the poll?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Have you collected them by tribes?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Assemble presently the people hither;
And when they bear me say 'It shall be so
I' the right and strength o' the commons,' be it either
For death, for fine, or banishment, then let them
If I say fine, cry 'Fine;' if death, cry 'Death.'
Insisting on the old prerogative
And power i' the truth o' the cause.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
And when such time they have begun to cry,
Let them not cease, but with a din confused
Enforce the present execution
Of what we chance to sentence.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Make them be strong and ready for this hint,
When we shall hap to give 't them.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Go about it.
Put him to choler straight

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Well, here he comes.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Calmly, I do beseech you.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Ay, as an ostler, that for the poorest piece
Will bear the knave by the volume. The honour'd gods
Keep Rome in safety, and the chairs of justice
Supplied with worthy men! plant love among 's!
Throng our large temples with the shows of peace,
And not our streets with war!

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: A noble wish.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Draw near, ye people.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: First, hear me speak.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Shall I be charged no further than this present?
Must all determine here?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
I do demand,
If you submit you to the people's voices,
Allow their officers and are content
To suffer lawful censure for such faults
As shall be proved upon you?

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: I am content.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Lo, citizens, he says he is content

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Scratches with briers,
Scars to move laughter only.

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
Consider further,
That when he speaks not like a citizen,
You find him like a soldier

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Well, well, no more.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
What is the matter
That being pass'd for consul with full voice,
I am so dishonour'd that the very hour
You take it off again?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Answer to us.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Say, then

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
We charge you, that you have contrived to take
From Rome all season'd office and to wind
Yourself into a power tyrannical;
For which you are a traitor to the people.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: How! traitor!

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Nay, temperately; your promise.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
The fires i' the lowest hell fold-in the people!
Call me their traitor! Thou injurious tribune!
Within thine eyes sat twenty thousand deaths,
In thy hand clutch'd as many millions, in
Thy lying tongue both numbers, I would say
'Thou liest' unto thee with a voice as free
As I do pray the gods.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Mark you this, people?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Peace!
We need not put new matter to his charge

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
But since he hath
Served well for Rome,--

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: What do you prate of service?

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: I talk of that, that know it.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: You?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Is this the promise that you made your mother?

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Know, I pray you,--

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: I know no further

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
For that he has,
As much as in him lies, from time to time
Envied against the people, seeking means
To pluck away their power, as now at last
Given hostile strokes, and that not in the presence
Of dreaded justice, but on the ministers
That do distribute it; in the name o' the people
And in the power of us the tribunes, we,
Even from this instant, banish him our city,
In peril of precipitation
From off the rock Tarpeian never more
To enter our Rome gates

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Hear me, my masters, and my common friends,--

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: He's sentenced; no more hearing.

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence: Let me speak

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: We know your drift

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
There's no more to be said, but he is banish'd,
As enemy to the people and his country

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
You common cry of curs! whose breath I hate
As reek o' the rotten fens, whose loves I prize
As the dead carcasses of unburied men
That do corrupt my air, I banish you;
And here remain with your uncertainty!
Let every feeble rumour shake your hearts!
Your enemies, with nodding of their plumes,
Fan you into despair! Have the power still
To banish your defenders; till at length
Your ignorance, which finds not till it feels,
Making not reservation of yourselves,
Still your own foes, deliver you as most
Abated captives to some nation
That won you without blows! Despising,
For you, the city, thus I turn my back

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Go, see him out at gates, and follow him,
As he hath followed you, with all despite;
Give him deserved vexation. Let a guard
Attend us through the city.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Come, leave your tears

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Nay! prithee, woman,--

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
What, what, what!
I shall be loved when I am lack'd. Nay, mother.
Resume that spirit, when you were wont to say,
If you had been the wife of Hercules,
Six of his labours you'ld have done, and saved
Your husband so much sweat. Cominius,
Droop not; adieu. Farewell, my wife, my mother

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: O the gods!

Speaker: COMINIUS
Sentence:
I'll follow thee a month, devise with thee
Where thou shalt rest, that thou mayst hear of us
And we of thee

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Fare ye well

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
That's worthily
As any ear can hear. Come, let's not weep.
If I could shake off but one seven years
From these old arms and legs, by the good gods,
I'ld with thee every foot.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Give me thy hand

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Bid them all home; he's gone, and we'll no further.
The nobility are vex'd, whom we see have sided
In his behalf.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Now we have shown our power,
Let us seem humbler after it is done
Than when it was a-doing.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Bid them home

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence:
Dismiss them home.
Here comes his mother.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Let's not meet her.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Why?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: They say she's mad.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: They have ta'en note of us

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Peace, peace; be not so loud.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: Are you mankind?

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: O blessed heavens!

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence: What then?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Come, come, peace.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
I would he had continued to his country
As he began, and not unknit himself
The noble knot he made.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: I would he had.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Pray, let us go.

Speaker: BRUTUS
Sentence: Well, well, we'll leave you.

Speaker: SICINIUS
Sentence:
Why stay we to be baited
With one that wants her wits?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence:
You have told them home;
And, by my troth, you have cause. You'll sup with me?

Speaker: MENENIUS
Sentence: Fie, fie, fie!

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
A goodly city is this Antium. City,
'Tis I that made thy widows

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Direct me, if it be your will,
Where great Aufidius lies

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Which is his house, beseech you?

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Thank you, sir

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: A goodly house

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
I have deserved no better entertainment,
In being Coriolanus.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Away!

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Now thou'rt troublesome.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Let me but stand; I will not hurt your hearth.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: A gentleman.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: True, so I am.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Follow your function, go, and batten on cold bits.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Under the canopy.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: Ay.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: I' the city of kites and crows.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence: No, I serve not thy master.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
Ay; 'tis an honester service than to meddle with thy
mistress. Thou pratest, and pratest; serve with thy
trencher, hence!

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
If, Tullus,
Not yet thou knowest me, and, seeing me, dost not
Think me for the man I am, necessity
Commands me name myself.

Speaker: CORIOLANUS
Sentence:
A name unmusical to the Volscians' ears,
And harsh in sound to thine.

Speaker: GLOUCESTER
Sentence:
Now is the winter of our discontent
Made glorious summer by this sun of York;
And all the clouds that lour'd upon our house
In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.
Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths;
Our bruised arms hung up for monuments;
Our stern alarums changed to merry meetings,
Our dreadful marches to delightful measures.
Grim-visaged war hath smooth'd his wrinkled front;
And now, instead of mounting barded steeds
To fright the souls of fearful adversaries,
He capers nimbly in a lady's chamber
To the lascivious pleasing of a lute.
But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks,
Nor made to court an amorous looking-glass;
I, that am rudely stamp'd, and want love's majesty
To strut before a wanton ambling nymph;
I, that am curtail'd of this fair proportion,
Cheated of feature by dissembling nature,
Deformed, unfinish'd, sent before my time
Into this breathing world, scarce half made up,
And that so lamely and unfashionable
That dogs bark at me as I halt by them;
Why, I, in this weak piping time of peace,
Have no delight to pass away the time,
Unless to spy my shadow in the sun
And descant on mine own deformity
