Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
Blind sight, dead life, poor mortal living ghost,
Woe's scene, world's shame, grave's due by life usurp'd,
Brief abstract and record of tedious days,
Rest thy unrest on England's lawful earth,
Unlawfully made drunk with innocents' blood!

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
O, that thou wouldst as well afford a grave
As thou canst yield a melancholy seat!
Then would I hide my bones, not rest them here.
O, who hath any cause to mourn but I?

Speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
Sentence:
If ancient sorrow be most reverend,
Give mine the benefit of seniory,
And let my woes frown on the upper hand.
If sorrow can admit society,
Tell o'er your woes again by viewing mine

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
I had a Richard too, and thou didst kill him;
I had a Rutland too, thou holp'st to kill him.

Speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
Sentence:
Thou hadst a Clarence too, and Richard kill'd him.
From forth the kennel of thy womb hath crept
A hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
O Harry's wife, triumph not in my woes!
God witness with me, I have wept for thine.

Speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
Sentence:
Bear with me; I am hungry for revenge,
And now I cloy me with beholding it.
Thy Edward he is dead, that stabb'd my Edward

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
O, thou didst prophesy the time would come
That I should wish for thee to help me curse
That bottled spider, that foul bunch-back'd toad!

Speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
O thou well skill'd in curses, stay awhile,
And teach me how to curse mine enemies!

Speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: My words are dull; O, quicken them with thine!

Speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
Sentence: Thy woes will make them sharp, and pierce like mine.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: Why should calamity be full of words?

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
Windy attorneys to their client woes,
Airy succeeders of intestate joys,
Poor breathing orators of miseries!
Let them have scope

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: If so, then be not tongue-tied

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Who intercepts my expedition?

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
O, she that might have intercepted thee,
By strangling thee in her accursed womb
From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done!

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
Hidest thou that forehead with a golden crown,
Where should be graven, if that right were right,
The slaughter of the prince that owed that crown,
And the dire death of my two sons and brothers?
Tell me, thou villain slave, where are my children?

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
Thou toad, thou toad, where is thy brother Clarence?
And little Ned Plantagenet, his son?

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: Where is kind Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
A flourish, trumpets! strike alarum, drums!
Let not the heavens hear these tell-tale women
Rail on the Lord's enointed

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: Art thou my son?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: Then patiently hear my impatience.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Madam, I have a touch of your condition,
Which cannot brook the accent of reproof.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: O, let me speak!

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Do then

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: I will be mild and gentle in my speech.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: And brief, good mother; for I am in haste.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
Art thou so hasty? I have stay'd for thee,
God knows, in anguish, pain and agony.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: And came I not at last to comfort you?

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
No, by the holy rood, thou know'st it well,
Thou camest on earth to make the earth my hell.
A grievous burthen was thy birth to me;
Tetchy and wayward was thy infancy;
Thy school-days frightful, desperate, wild, and furious,
Thy prime of manhood daring, bold, and venturous,
Thy age confirm'd, proud, subdued, bloody,
treacherous,
More mild, but yet more harmful, kind in hatred

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Faith, none, but Humphrey Hour, that call'd
your grace
To breakfast once forth of my company.
If I be so disgracious in your sight,
Let me march on, and not offend your grace.
Strike the drum.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: I prithee, hear me speak.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: You speak too bitterly.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
Hear me a word;
For I shall never speak to thee again.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: So.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
Either thou wilt die, by God's just ordinance,
Ere from this war thou turn a conqueror,
Or I with grief and extreme age shall perish
And never look upon thy face again.
Therefore take with thee my most heavy curse;
Which, in the day of battle, tire thee more
Than all the complete armour that thou wear'st!
My prayers on the adverse party fight;
And there the little souls of Edward's children
Whisper the spirits of thine enemies
And promise them success and victory.
Bloody thou art, bloody will be thy end;
Shame serves thy life and doth thy death attend.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curse
Abides in me; I say amen to all.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Stay, madam; I must speak a word with you.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
I have no more sons of the royal blood
For thee to murder

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
You have a daughter call'd Elizabeth,
Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Wrong not her birth, she is of royal blood.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: To save her life, I'll say she is not so.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Her life is only safest in her birth.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: And only in that safety died her brothers.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Lo, at their births good stars were opposite.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: No, to their lives bad friends were contrary.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: All unavoided is the doom of destiny.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: True, when avoided grace makes destiny

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: You speak as if that I had slain my cousins.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
Cousins, indeed; and by their uncle cozen'd
Of comfort, kingdom, kindred, freedom, life.
Whose hand soever lanced their tender hearts,
Thy head, all indirectly, gave direction

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Madam, so thrive I in my enterprise
And dangerous success of bloody wars,
As I intend more good to you and yours,
Than ever you or yours were by me wrong'd!

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
What good is cover'd with the face of heaven,
To be discover'd, that can do me good?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: The advancement of your children, gentle lady.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: Up to some scaffold, there to lose their heads?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
No, to the dignity and height of honour
The high imperial type of this earth's glory.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Even all I have; yea, and myself and all,
Will I withal endow a child of thine;
So in the Lethe of thy angry soul
Thou drown the sad remembrance of those wrongs
Which thou supposest I have done to thee.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
Be brief, lest that be process of thy kindness
Last longer telling than thy kindness' date.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Then know, that from my soul I love thy daughter.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: My daughter's mother thinks it with her soul.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: What do you think?

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Be not so hasty to confound my meaning

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: Say then, who dost thou mean shall be her king?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Even he that makes her queen who should be else?

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: What, thou?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: I, even I

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: How canst thou woo her?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
That would I learn of you,
As one that are best acquainted with her humour.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: And wilt thou learn of me?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Madam, with all my heart.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
Send to her, by the man that slew her brothers,
A pair of bleeding-hearts; thereon engrave
Edward and York; then haply she will weep

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Come, come, you mock me; this is not the way
To win our daughter.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
There is no other way
Unless thou couldst put on some other shape,
And not be Richard that hath done all this.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Say that I did all this for love of her.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
Nay, then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee,
Having bought love with such a bloody spoil.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Look, what is done cannot be now amended

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
What were I best to say? her father's brother
Would be her lord? or shall I say, her uncle?
Or, he that slew her brothers and her uncles?
Under what title shall I woo for thee,
That God, the law, my honour and her love,
Can make seem pleasing to her tender years?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Infer fair England's peace by this alliance.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: Which she shall purchase with still lasting war.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Say that the king, which may command, entreats.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: That at her hands which the king's King forbids.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Say, she shall be a high and mighty queen.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: To wail the tide, as her mother doth.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Say, I will love her everlastingly.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: But how long shall that title 'ever' last?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Sweetly in force unto her fair life's end.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: But how long fairly shall her sweet lie last?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: So long as heaven and nature lengthens it.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: So long as hell and Richard likes of it.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Say, I, her sovereign, am her subject love.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: But she, your subject, loathes such sovereignty.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Be eloquent in my behalf to her.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: An honest tale speeds best being plainly told.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Then in plain terms tell her my loving tale.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
O no, my reasons are too deep and dead;
Too deep and dead, poor infants, in their grave.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Harp not on that string, madam; that is past.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Now, by my George, my garter, and my crown,--

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: Profaned, dishonour'd, and the third usurp'd.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: I swear--

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: By nothing; for this is no oath

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Now, by the world--

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: 'Tis full of thy foul wrongs.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: My father's death--

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: Thy life hath that dishonour'd.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Then, by myself--

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: Thyself thyself misusest.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Why then, by God--

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
God's wrong is most of all.
If thou hadst fear'd to break an oath by Him,
The unity the king thy brother made
Had not been broken, nor my brother slain

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: The time to come.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
That thou hast wronged in the time o'erpast;
For I myself have many tears to wash
Hereafter time, for time past wrong'd by thee.
The children live, whose parents thou hast
slaughter'd,
Ungovern'd youth, to wail it in their age;
The parents live, whose children thou hast butcher'd,
Old wither'd plants, to wail it with their age.
Swear not by time to come; for that thou hast
Misused ere used, by time misused o'erpast.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
As I intend to prosper and repent,
So thrive I in my dangerous attempt
Of hostile arms! myself myself confound!
Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours!
Day, yield me not thy light; nor, night, thy rest!
Be opposite all planets of good luck
To my proceedings, if, with pure heart's love,
Immaculate devotion, holy thoughts,
I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter!
In her consists my happiness and thine;
Without her, follows to this land and me,
To thee, herself, and many a Christian soul,
Death, desolation, ruin and decay

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: Shall I be tempted of the devil thus?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Ay, if the devil tempt thee to do good.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: Shall I forget myself to be myself?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Ay, if yourself's remembrance wrong yourself.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: But thou didst kill my children.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: But in your daughter's womb I bury them

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: And be a happy mother by the deed.

Speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
Sentence:
I go. Write to me very shortly.
And you shall understand from me her mind.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Bear her my true love's kiss; and so, farewell.
Relenting fool, and shallow, changing woman!
How now! what news?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Some light-foot friend post to the Duke of Norfolk

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Fly to the duke

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: O, true, good Catesby

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Why, what wouldst thou do there before I go?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
My mind is changed, sir, my mind is changed.
How now, what news with you?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Hoyday, a riddle! neither good nor bad!
Why dost thou run so many mile about,
When thou mayst tell thy tale a nearer way?
Once more, what news?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
There let him sink, and be the seas on him!
White-liver'd runagate, what doth he there?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Well, sir, as you guess, as you guess?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Is the chair empty? is the sword unsway'd?
Is the king dead? the empire unpossess'd?
What heir of York is there alive but we?
And who is England's king but great York's heir?
Then, tell me, what doth he upon the sea?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Unless for that he comes to be your liege,
You cannot guess wherefore the Welshman comes.
Thou wilt revolt, and fly to him, I fear.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Where is thy power, then, to beat him back?
Where are thy tenants and thy followers?
Are they not now upon the western shore.
Safe-conducting the rebels from their ships!

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Cold friends to Richard

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Ay, ay. thou wouldst be gone to join with Richmond

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Well,
Go muster men; but, hear you, leave behind
Your son, George Stanley

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Out on you, owls! nothing but songs of death?
Take that, until thou bring me better news.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: I cry thee mercy

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Away towards Salisbury! while we reason here,
A royal battle might be won and lost
Some one take order Buckingham be brought
To Salisbury; the rest march on with me.

Speaker: BUCKINGHAM
Sentence: Will not King Richard let me speak with him?

Speaker: BUCKINGHAM
Sentence:
Hastings, and Edward's children, Rivers, Grey,
Holy King Henry, and thy fair son Edward,
Vaughan, and all that have miscarried
By underhand corrupted foul injustice,
If that your moody discontented souls
Do through the clouds behold this present hour,
Even for revenge mock my destruction!
This is All-Souls' day, fellows, is it not?

Speaker: BUCKINGHAM
Sentence:
Why, then All-Souls' day is my body's doomsday.
This is the day that, in King Edward's time,
I wish't might fall on me, when I was found
False to his children or his wife's allies
This is the day wherein I wish'd to fall
By the false faith of him I trusted most;
This, this All-Souls' day to my fearful soul
Is the determined respite of my wrongs

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Here pitch our tents, even here in Bosworth field.
My Lord of Surrey, why look you so sad?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: My Lord of Norfolk,--

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Norfolk, we must have knocks; ha! must we not?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Why, our battalion trebles that account

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: What is't o'clock?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
I will not sup to-night.
Give me some ink and paper.
What, is my beaver easier than it was?
And all my armour laid into my tent?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Good Norfolk, hie thee to thy charge;
Use careful watch, choose trusty sentinels.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Stir with the lark to-morrow, gentle Norfolk.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Catesby!

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Send out a pursuivant at arms
To Stanley's regiment; bid him bring his power
Before sunrising, lest his son George fall
Into the blind cave of eternal night.
Fill me a bowl of wine. Give me a watch.
Saddle white Surrey for the field to-morrow.
Look that my staves be sound, and not too heavy.
Ratcliff!

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Saw'st thou the melancholy Lord Northumberland?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: So, I am satisfied. Give me a bowl of wine

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Bid my guard watch; leave me.
Ratcliff, about the mid of night come to my tent
And help to arm me. Leave me, I say.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Give me another horse

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: 'Zounds! who is there?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
O Ratcliff, I have dream'd a fearful dream!
What thinkest thou, will our friends prove all true?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: O Ratcliff, I fear, I fear,--

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
By the apostle Paul, shadows to-night
Have struck more terror to the soul of Richard
Than can the substance of ten thousand soldiers
Armed in proof, and led by shallow Richmond.
It is not yet near day. Come, go with me;
Under our tents I'll play the eaves-dropper,
To see if any mean to shrink from me.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: What said Northumberland as touching Richmond?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: He said the truth

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
He was in the right; and so indeed it is.
Ten the clock there. Give me a calendar.
Who saw the sun to-day?

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Then he disdains to shine; for by the book
He should have braved the east an hour ago
A black day will it be to somebody. Ratcliff!

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
The sun will not be seen to-day;
The sky doth frown and lour upon our army.
I would these dewy tears were from the ground.
Not shine to-day! Why, what is that to me
More than to Richmond?  for the selfsame heaven
That frowns on me looks sadly upon him.

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Come, bustle, bustle; caparison my horse.
Call up Lord Stanley, bid him bring his power

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: Off with his son George's head!

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: A thousand hearts are great within my bosom

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence: A horse! a horse! my kingdom for a horse!

Speaker: KING RICHARD III
Sentence:
Slave, I have set my life upon a cast,
And I will stand the hazard of the die

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Old John of Gaunt, time-honour'd Lancaster,
Hast thou, according to thy oath and band,
Brought hither Henry Hereford thy bold son,
Here to make good the boisterous late appeal,
Which then our leisure would not let us hear,
Against the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray?

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Tell me, moreover, hast thou sounded him,
If he appeal the duke on ancient malice;
Or worthily, as a good subject should,
On some known ground of treachery in him?

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Then call them to our presence; face to face,
And frowning brow to brow, ourselves will hear
The accuser and the accused freely speak

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Many years of happy days befal
My gracious sovereign, my most loving liege!

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: We thank you both

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
First, heaven be the record to my speech!
In the devotion of a subject's love,
Tendering the precious safety of my prince,
And free from other misbegotten hate,
Come I appellant to this princely presence.
Now, Thomas Mowbray, do I turn to thee,
And mark my greeting well; for what I speak
My body shall make good upon this earth,
Or my divine soul answer it in heaven.
Thou art a traitor and a miscreant,
Too good to be so and too bad to live,
Since the more fair and crystal is the sky,
The uglier seem the clouds that in it fly.
Once more, the more to aggravate the note,
With a foul traitor's name stuff I thy throat;
And wish, so please my sovereign, ere I move,
What my tongue speaks my right drawn sword may prove.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Pale trembling coward, there I throw my gage,
Disclaiming here the kindred of the king,
And lay aside my high blood's royalty,
Which fear, not reverence, makes thee to except.
If guilty dread have left thee so much strength
As to take up mine honour's pawn, then stoop

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
What doth our cousin lay to Mowbray's charge?
It must be great that can inherit us
So much as of a thought of ill in him.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Look, what I speak, my life shall prove it true;
That Mowbray hath received eight thousand nobles
In name of lendings for your highness' soldiers,
The which he hath detain'd for lewd employments,
Like a false traitor and injurious villain.
Besides I say and will in battle prove,
Or here or elsewhere to the furthest verge
That ever was survey'd by English eye,
That all the treasons for these eighteen years
Complotted and contrived in this land
Fetch from false Mowbray their first head and spring.
Further I say and further will maintain
Upon his bad life to make all this good,
That he did plot the Duke of Gloucester's death,
Suggest his soon-believing adversaries,
And consequently, like a traitor coward,
Sluiced out his innocent soul through streams of blood

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
How high a pitch his resolution soars!
Thomas of Norfolk, what say'st thou to this?

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Mowbray, impartial are our eyes and ears

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Wrath-kindled gentlemen, be ruled by me;
Let's purge this choler without letting blood

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: And, Norfolk, throw down his.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Norfolk, throw down, we bid; there is no boot.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Rage must be withstood

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Cousin, throw up your gage; do you begin.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
O, God defend my soul from such deep sin!
Shall I seem crest-fall'n in my father's sight?
Or with pale beggar-fear impeach my height
Before this out-dared dastard? Ere my tongue
Shall wound my honour with such feeble wrong,
Or sound so base a parle, my teeth shall tear
The slavish motive of recanting fear,
And spit it bleeding in his high disgrace,
Where shame doth harbour, even in Mowbray's face.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
We were not born to sue, but to command;
Which since we cannot do to make you friends,
Be ready, as your lives shall answer it,
At Coventry, upon Saint Lambert's day

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Marshal, demand of yonder champion
The cause of his arrival here in arms

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Marshal, ask yonder knight in arms,
Both who he is and why he cometh hither
Thus plated in habiliments of war,
And formally, according to our law,
Depose him in the justice of his cause.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Harry of Hereford, Lancaster and Derby
Am I; who ready here do stand in arms,
To prove, by God's grace and my body's valour,
In lists, on Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk,
That he is a traitor, foul and dangerous,
To God of heaven, King Richard and to me;
And as I truly fight, defend me heaven!

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Lord marshal, let me kiss my sovereign's hand,
And bow my knee before his majesty

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
We will descend and fold him in our arms.
Cousin of Hereford, as thy cause is right,
So be thy fortune in this royal fight!
Farewell, my blood; which if to-day thou shed,
Lament we may, but not revenge thee dead.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
O let no noble eye profane a tear
For me, if I be gored with Mowbray's spear

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Mine innocency and Saint George to thrive!

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Farewell, my lord

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Strong as a tower in hope, I cry amen.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Let them lay by their helmets and their spears,
And both return back to their chairs again

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Your will be done

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Norfolk, for thee remains a heavier doom,
Which I with some unwillingness pronounce

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: It boots thee not to be compassionate

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Return again, and take an oath with thee.
Lay on our royal sword your banish'd hands;
Swear by the duty that you owe to God--
Our part therein we banish with yourselves--
To keep the oath that we administer

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: I swear.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Norfolk, so far as to mine enemy

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Uncle, even in the glasses of thine eyes
I see thy grieved heart

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
How long a time lies in one little word!
Four lagging winters and four wanton springs
End in a word

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Why uncle, thou hast many years to live.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Thy son is banish'd upon good advice,
Whereto thy tongue a party-verdict gave

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Cousin, farewell; and, uncle, bid him so

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
I have too few to take my leave of you,
When the tongue's office should be prodigal
To breathe the abundant dolour of the heart.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Joy absent, grief is present for that time.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: To men in joy; but grief makes one hour ten.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
My heart will sigh when I miscall it so,
Which finds it an inforced pilgrimage.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Nay, rather, every tedious stride I make
Will but remember me what a deal of world
I wander from the jewels that I love.
Must I not serve a long apprenticehood
To foreign passages, and in the end,
Having my freedom, boast of nothing else
But that I was a journeyman to grief?

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
O, who can hold a fire in his hand
By thinking on the frosty Caucasus?
Or cloy the hungry edge of appetite
By bare imagination of a feast?
Or wallow naked in December snow
By thinking on fantastic summer's heat?
O, no! the apprehension of the good
Gives but the greater feeling to the worse

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Then, England's ground, farewell; sweet soil, adieu;
My mother, and my nurse, that bears me yet!
Where'er I wander, boast of this I can,
Though banish'd, yet a trueborn Englishman.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
We did observe. Cousin Aumerle,
How far brought you high Hereford on his way?

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: And say, what store of parting tears were shed?

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: What said our cousin when you parted with him?

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
He is our cousin, cousin; but 'tis doubt,
When time shall call him home from banishment,
Whether our kinsman come to see his friends.
Ourself and Bushy, Bagot here and Green
Observed his courtship to the common people;
How he did seem to dive into their hearts
With humble and familiar courtesy,
What reverence he did throw away on slaves,
Wooing poor craftsmen with the craft of smiles
And patient underbearing of his fortune,
As 'twere to banish their affects with him.
Off goes his bonnet to an oyster-wench;
A brace of draymen bid God speed him well
And had the tribute of his supple knee,
With 'Thanks, my countrymen, my loving friends;'
As were our England in reversion his,
And he our subjects' next degree in hope.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: We will ourself in person to this war

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Where lies he?

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Now put it, God, in the physician's mind
To help him to his grave immediately!
The lining of his coffers shall make coats
To deck our soldiers for these Irish wars.
Come, gentlemen, let's all go visit him

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: What comfort, man? how is't with aged Gaunt?

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Can sick men play so nicely with their names?

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Should dying men flatter with those that live?

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Thou, now a-dying, say'st thou flatterest me.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: I am in health, I breathe, and see thee ill.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
A lunatic lean-witted fool,
Presuming on an ague's privilege,
Darest with thy frozen admonition
Make pale our cheek, chasing the royal blood
With fury from his native residence.
Now, by my seat's right royal majesty,
Wert thou not brother to great Edward's son,
This tongue that runs so roundly in thy head
Should run thy head from thy unreverent shoulders.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
And let them die that age and sullens have;
For both hast thou, and both become the grave.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Right, you say true

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: What says he?

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Why, uncle, what's the matter?

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Think what you will, we seize into our hands
His plate, his goods, his money and his lands.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Go, Bushy, to the Earl of Wiltshire straight

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: How far is it, my lord, to Berkeley now?

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Of much less value is my company
Than your good words. But who comes here?

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
I thank thee, gentle Percy; and be sure
I count myself in nothing else so happy
As in a soul remembering my good friends;
And, as my fortune ripens with thy love,
It shall be still thy true love's recompense

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Welcome, my lords. I wot your love pursues
A banish'd traitor

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
HENRY BOLINGBROKE
HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
I shall not need transport my words by you;
Here comes his grace in person. My noble uncle!

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: My gracious uncle--

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: My gracious uncle, let me know my fault

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
As I was banish'd, I was banish'd Hereford;
But as I come, I come for Lancaster.
And, noble uncle, I beseech your grace
Look on my wrongs with an indifferent eye

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: An offer, uncle, that we will accept

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Bring forth these men.
Bushy and Green, I will not vex your souls--
Since presently your souls must part your bodies--
With too much urging your pernicious lives,
For 'twere no charity; yet, to wash your blood
From off my hands, here in the view of men
I will unfold some causes of your deaths.
You have misled a prince, a royal king,
A happy gentleman in blood and lineaments,
By you unhappied and disfigured clean

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Thank, gentle uncle. Come, lords, away.
To fight with Glendower and his complices

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Barkloughly castle call they this at hand?

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Needs must I like it well

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Discomfortable cousin! know'st thou not
That when the searching eye of heaven is hid,
Behind the globe, that lights the lower world,
Then thieves and robbers range abroad unseen
In murders and in outrage, boldly here;
But when from under this terrestrial ball
He fires the proud tops of the eastern pines
And darts his light through every guilty hole,
Then murders, treasons and detested sins,
The cloak of night being pluck'd from off their backs,
Stand bare and naked, trembling at themselves?
So when this thief, this traitor, Bolingbroke,
Who all this while hath revell'd in the night
Whilst we were wandering with the antipodes,
Shall see us rising in our throne, the east,
His treasons will sit blushing in his face,
Not able to endure the sight of day,
But self-affrighted tremble at his sin.
Not all the water in the rough rude sea
Can wash the balm off from an anointed king;
The breath of worldly men cannot depose
The deputy elected by the Lord

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
But now the blood of twenty thousand men
Did triumph in my face, and they are fled;
And, till so much blood thither come again,
Have I not reason to look pale and dead?
All souls that will be safe fly from my side,
For time hath set a blot upon my pride.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
I had forgot myself; am I not king?
Awake, thou coward majesty! thou sleepest.
Is not the king's name twenty thousand names?
Arm, arm, my name! a puny subject strikes
At thy great glory. Look not to the ground,
Ye favourites of a king

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Mine ear is open and my heart prepared;
The worst is worldly loss thou canst unfold.
Say, is my kingdom lost? why, 'twas my care
And what loss is it to be rid of care?
Strives Bolingbroke to be as great as we?
Greater he shall not be; if he serve God,
We'll serve Him too and be his fellow so

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Too well, too well thou tell'st a tale so ill.
Where is the Earl of Wiltshire? where is Bagot?
What is become of Bushy? where is Green?
That they have let the dangerous enemy
Measure our confines with such peaceful steps?
If we prevail, their heads shall pay for it

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
O villains, vipers, damn'd without redemption!
Dogs, easily won to fawn on any man!
Snakes, in my heart-blood warm'd, that sting my heart!
Three Judases, each one thrice worse than Judas!
Would they make peace? terrible hell make war
Upon their spotted souls for this offence!

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: No matter where; of comfort no man speak

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Thou chidest me well

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Thou hast said enough.
Beshrew thee, cousin, which didst lead me forth
Of that sweet way I was in to despair!
What say you now? what comfort have we now?
By heaven, I'll hate him everlastingly
That bids me be of comfort any more.
Go to Flint castle

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
He does me double wrong
That wounds me with the flatteries of his tongue.
Discharge my followers

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
So that by this intelligence we learn
The Welshmen are dispersed, and Salisbury
Is gone to meet the king, who lately landed
With some few private friends upon this coast.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Mistake not, uncle, further than you should.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
I know it, uncle, and oppose not myself
Against their will. But who comes here?
Welcome, Harry

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Royally!
Why, it contains no king?

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Noble lords,
Go to the rude ribs of that ancient castle;
Through brazen trumpet send the breath of parley
Into his ruin'd ears, and thus deliver

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
We are amazed; and thus long have we stood
To watch the fearful bending of thy knee,
Because we thought ourself thy lawful king

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Northumberland, say thus the king returns

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
O God, O God! that e'er this tongue of mine,
That laid the sentence of dread banishment
On yon proud man, should take it off again
With words of sooth! O that I were as great
As is my grief, or lesser than my name!
Or that I could forget what I have been,
Or not remember what I must be now!
Swell'st thou, proud heart? I'll give thee scope to beat,
Since foes have scope to beat both thee and me.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
What must the king do now? must he submit?
The king shall do it

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Down, down I come; like glistering Phaethon,
Wanting the manage of unruly jades.
In the base court? Base court, where kings grow base,
To come at traitors' calls and do them grace.
In the base court? Come down? Down, court!
down, king!
For night-owls shriek where mounting larks
should sing.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: What says his majesty?

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Stand all apart,
And show fair duty to his majesty.
My gracious lord,--

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Fair cousin, you debase your princely knee
To make the base earth proud with kissing it

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: My gracious lord, I come but for mine own.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Your own is yours, and I am yours, and all.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
So far be mine, my most redoubted lord,
As my true service shall deserve your love.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Well you deserve

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Yea, my good lord.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Then I must not say no.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Call forth Bagot.
Now, Bagot, freely speak thy mind;
What thou dost know of noble Gloucester's death,
Who wrought it with the king, and who perform'd
The bloody office of his timeless end.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Cousin, stand forth, and look upon that man.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Bagot, forbear; thou shalt not take it up.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
These differences shall all rest under gage
Till Norfolk be repeal'd

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Why, bishop, is Norfolk dead?

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Sweet peace conduct his sweet soul to the bosom
Of good old Abraham! Lords appellants,
Your differences shall all rest under gage
Till we assign you to your days of trial.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: In God's name, I'll ascend the regal throne.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Fetch hither Richard, that in common view
He may surrender; so we shall proceed
Without suspicion.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Lords, you that here are under our arrest,
Procure your sureties for your days of answer.
Little are we beholding to your love,
And little look'd for at your helping hands.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Alack, why am I sent for to a king,
Before I have shook off the regal thoughts
Wherewith I reign'd? I hardly yet have learn'd
To insinuate, flatter, bow, and bend my limbs

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Give me the crown. Here, cousin, seize the crown;
Here cousin

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: I thought you had been willing to resign.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: My crown I am; but still my griefs are mine

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Part of your cares you give me with your crown.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Are you contented to resign the crown?

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Must I do so? and must I ravel out
My weaved-up folly? Gentle Northumberland,
If thy offences were upon record,
Would it not shame thee in so fair a troop
To read a lecture of them? If thou wouldst,
There shouldst thou find one heinous article,
Containing the deposing of a king
And cracking the strong warrant of an oath,
Mark'd with a blot, damn'd in the book of heaven

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Mine eyes are full of tears, I cannot see

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
No lord of thine, thou haught insulting man,
Nor no man's lord; I have no name, no title,
No, not that name was given me at the font,
But 'tis usurp'd

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Go some of you and fetch a looking-glass.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Fiend, thou torment'st me ere I come to hell!

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Urge it no more, my Lord Northumberland.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: They shall be satisfied

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
The shadow of your sorrow hath destroy'd
The shadow or your face.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Say that again.
The shadow of my sorrow! ha! let's see

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Name it, fair cousin.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: 'Fair cousin'? I am greater than a king

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Yet ask.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: And shall I have?

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: You shall.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Then give me leave to go.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Whither?

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Whither you will, so I were from your sights.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Go, some of you convey him to the Tower.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
O, good! convey? conveyers are you all,
That rise thus nimbly by a true king's fall.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
On Wednesday next we solemnly set down
Our coronation

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Join not with grief, fair woman, do not so,
To make my end too sudden

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
A king of beasts, indeed; if aught but beasts,
I had been still a happy king of men.
Good sometime queen, prepare thee hence for France

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Northumberland, thou ladder wherewithal
The mounting Bolingbroke ascends my throne,
The time shall not be many hours of age
More than it is ere foul sin gathering head
Shalt break into corruption

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
Doubly divorced! Bad men, you violate
A twofold marriage, 'twixt my crown and me,
And then betwixt me and my married wife.
Let me unkiss the oath 'twixt thee and me;
And yet not so, for with a kiss 'twas made.
Part us, Northumberland; I toward the north,
Where shivering cold and sickness pines the clime;
My wife to France

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence: Ay, hand from hand, my love, and heart from heart.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
Sentence:
So two, together weeping, make one woe.
Weep thou for me in France, I for thee here;
Better far off than near, be ne'er the near.
Go, count thy way with sighs; I mine with groans.

Speaker: KING RICHARD II
KING RICHARD II
Sentence: We make woe wanton with this fond delay

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
My lord, you told me you would tell the rest,
When weeping made you break the story off,
of our two cousins coming into London.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
At that sad stop, my lord,
Where rude misgovern'd hands from windows' tops
Threw dust and rubbish on King Richard's head.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: Alack, poor Richard! where rode he the whilst?

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: Here comes my son Aumerle.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: Welcome, my son

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
What should you fear?
'Tis nothing but some bond, that he is enter'd into
For gay apparel 'gainst the triumph day.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: What is the matter, my lord?

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: Why, what is it, my lord?

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: What is the matter?

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: I will not peace. What is the matter, Aumerle.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: Thy life answer!

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
Strike him, Aumerle. Poor boy, thou art amazed.
Hence, villain! never more come in my sight.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
Why, York, what wilt thou do?
Wilt thou not hide the trespass of thine own?
Have we more sons? or are we like to have?
Is not my teeming date drunk up with time?
And wilt thou pluck my fair son from mine age,
And rob me of a happy mother's name?
Is he not like thee? is he not thine own?

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
He shall be none;
We'll keep him here

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
Hadst thou groan'd for him
As I have done, thou wouldst be more pitiful.
But now I know thy mind; thou dost suspect
That I have been disloyal to thy bed,
And that he is a bastard, not thy son

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
After, Aumerle! mount thee upon his horse;
Spur post, and get before him to the king,
And beg thy pardon ere he do accuse thee.
I'll not be long behind; though I be old,
I doubt not but to ride as fast as York

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Can no man tell me of my unthrifty son?
'Tis full three months since I did see him last;
If any plague hang over us, 'tis he.
I would to God, my lords, he might be found

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: And what said the gallant?

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
As dissolute as desperate; yet through both
I see some sparks of better hope, which elder years
May happily bring forth. But who comes here?

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
What means our cousin, that he stares and looks
So wildly?

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Withdraw yourselves, and leave us here alone.
What is the matter with our cousin now?

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Intended or committed was this fault?
If on the first, how heinous e'er it be,
To win thy after-love I pardon thee.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Have thy desire.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Villain, I'll make thee safe.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
O heinous, strong and bold conspiracy!
O loyal father of a treacherous son!
Thou sheer, immaculate and silver fountain,
From when this stream through muddy passages
Hath held his current and defiled himself!
Thy overflow of good converts to bad,
And thy abundant goodness shall excuse
This deadly blot in thy digressing son.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: What shrill-voiced suppliant makes this eager cry?

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
A woman, and thy aunt, great king; 'tis I.
Speak with me, pity me, open the door.
A beggar begs that never begg'd before.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
Our scene is alter'd from a serious thing,
And now changed to 'The Beggar and the King.'
My dangerous cousin, let your mother in

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
O king, believe not this hard-hearted man!
Love loving not itself none other can.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: Sweet York, be patient. Hear me, gentle liege.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Rise up, good aunt.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence: Not yet, I thee beseech

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Good aunt, stand up.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
Nay, do not say, 'stand up;'
Say, 'pardon' first, and afterwards 'stand up.'
And if I were thy nurse, thy tongue to teach,
'Pardon' should be the first word of thy speech.
I never long'd to hear a word till now;
Say 'pardon,' king; let pity teach thee how

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: Good aunt, stand up.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
I do not sue to stand;
Pardon is all the suit I have in hand.

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence: I pardon him, as God shall pardon me.

Speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Sentence:
O happy vantage of a kneeling knee!
Yet am I sick for fear

Speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
Sentence:
With all my heart
I pardon him.

Speaker: QUEEN MARGARET

Speaker: WARWICK

Speaker: WARWICK
Sentence:

Ah, who is nigh? come to me, friend or foe,

Why ask I that? my mangled body shows,
My blood, my want of strength, my sick heart shows.
That I must yield my body to the earth
And, by my fall, the conquest to my foe.
Thus yields the cedar to the axe's edge,
Whose arms gave shelter to the princely eagle,
Under whose shade the ramping lion slept,
Whose top-branch overpeer'd Jove's spreading tree
And kept low shrubs from winter's powerful wind.
These eyes, that now are dimm'd with death's black veil,
Have been as piercing as the mid-day sun,
To search the secret treasons of the world

Speaker: WARWICK

That glues my lips and will not let me speak.
Come quickly, Montague, or I am dead.

Speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
Sentence:
Great lords, wise men ne'er sit and wail their loss,
But cheerly seek how to redress their harms.
What though the mast be now blown overboard,
The cable broke, the holding-anchor lost,
And half our sailors swallow'd in the flood?
Yet lives our pilot still. Is't meet that he
Should leave the helm and like a fearful lad
With tearful eyes add water to the sea
And give more strength to that which hath too much,
Whiles, in his moan, the ship splits on the rock,
Which industry and courage might have saved?
Ah, what a shame! ah, what a fault were this!
Say Warwick was our anchor; what of that?
And Montague our topmost; what of him?
Our slaughter'd friends the tackles; what of these?
Why, is not Oxford here another anchor?
And Somerset another goodly mast?
The friends of France our shrouds and tacklings?
And, though unskilful, why not Ned and I
For once allow'd the skilful pilot's charge?
We will not from the helm to sit and weep,
But keep our course, though the rough wind say no,
From shelves and rocks that threaten us with wreck.
As good to chide the waves as speak them fair.
And what is Edward but ruthless sea?
What Clarence but a quicksand of deceit?
And Richard but a ragged fatal rock?
All these the enemies to our poor bark.
Say you can swim; alas, 'tis but a while!
Tread on the sand; why, there you quickly sink

Speaker: GLOUCESTER
Sentence:

Speaker: KING HENRY VI
Sentence:
I, Daedalus; my poor boy, Icarus;
Thy father, Minos, that denied our course;
The sun that sear'd the wings of my sweet boy
Thy brother Edward, and thyself the sea
Whose envious gulf did swallow up his life.
Ah, kill me with thy weapon, not with words!
My breast can better brook thy dagger's point
Than can my ears that tragic history.
But wherefore dost thou come? is't for my life?

Speaker: GLOUCESTER

Speaker: KING HENRY VI

Speaker: KING HENRY VI
Sentence:
Hadst thou been kill'd when first thou didst presume,
Thou hadst not lived to kill a son of mine.
And thus I prophesy, that many a thousand,
Which now mistrust no parcel of my fear,
And many an old man's sigh and many a widow's,
And many an orphan's water-standing eye--
Men for their sons, wives for their husbands,
And orphans for their parents timeless death--
Shall rue the hour that ever thou wast born.
The owl shriek'd at thy birth,--an evil sign;
The night-crow cried, aboding luckless time;
Dogs howl'd, and hideous tempest shook down trees;
The raven rook'd her on the chimney's top,
And chattering pies in dismal discords sung.
Thy mother felt more than a mother's pain,
And, yet brought forth less than a mother's hope,
To wit, an indigested and deformed lump,
Not like the fruit of such a goodly tree.
Teeth hadst thou in thy head when thou wast born,
To signify thou camest to bite the world

From those that wish the downfall of our house!
If any spark of life be yet remaining,
Down, down to hell; and say I sent thee thither

Speaker: KING EDWARD IV
Sentence:
Once more we sit in England's royal throne,
Re-purchased with the blood of enemies.
What valiant foemen, like to autumn's corn,
Have we mow'd down, in tops of all their pride!
Three Dukes of Somerset, threefold renown'd
For hardy and undoubted champions;
Two Cliffords, as the father and the son,
And two Northumberlands; two braver men
Ne'er spurr'd their coursers at the trumpet's sound;
With them, the two brave bears, Warwick and Montague,
That in their chains fetter'd the kingly lion
And made the forest tremble when they roar'd.
Thus have we swept suspicion from our seat
And made our footstool of security.
Come hither, Bess, and let me kiss my boy.
Young Ned, for thee, thine uncles and myself
Have in our armours watch'd the winter's night,
Went all afoot in summer's scalding heat,
That thou mightst repossess the crown in peace;
And of our labours thou shalt reap the gain.

Speaker: KING EDWARD IV
Sentence:

And kiss your princely nephew, brothers both.

Speaker: CLARENCE

Speaker: KING EDWARD IV

Speaker: CLARENCE

Speaker: KING EDWARD IV
Sentence:

And now what rests but that we spend the time
With stately triumphs, mirthful comic shows,
Such as befits the pleasure of the court?
Sound drums and trumpets! farewell sour annoy!
For here, I hope, begins our lasting joy.

To nothing temporal.

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence: Well; come to me to-morrow.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: Heaven keep your honour safe!

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
At what hour to-morrow
Shall I attend your lordship?

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence: At any time 'fore noon.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: 'Save your honour!

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
From thee, even from thy virtue!
What's this, what's this? Is this her fault or mine?
The tempter or the tempted, who sins most?
Ha!
Not she

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: Hail to you, provost! so I think you are.

Speaker: Provost
Sentence: I am the provost. What's your will, good friar?

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
Bound by my charity and my blest order,
I come to visit the afflicted spirits
Here in the prison. Do me the common right
To let me see them and to make me know
The nature of their crimes, that I may minister
To them accordingly.

Speaker: Provost
Sentence:
I would do more than that, if more were needful.
Look, here comes one

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: When must he die?

Speaker: Provost
Sentence:
As I do think, to-morrow.
I have provided for you

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: Repent you, fair one, of the sin you carry?

Speaker: JULIET
Sentence: I do; and bear the shame most patiently.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
I'll teach you how you shall arraign your conscience,
And try your penitence, if it be sound,
Or hollowly put on.

Speaker: JULIET
Sentence: I'll gladly learn.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: Love you the man that wrong'd you?

Speaker: JULIET
Sentence: Yes, as I love the woman that wrong'd him.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
So then it seems your most offenceful act
Was mutually committed?

Speaker: JULIET
Sentence: Mutually.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: Then was your sin of heavier kind than his.

Speaker: JULIET
Sentence: I do confess it, and repent it, father.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: 'Tis meet so, daughter

Speaker: JULIET
Sentence:
I do repent me, as it is an evil,
And take the shame with joy.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
There rest.
Your partner, as I hear, must die to-morrow,
And I am going with instruction to him.
Grace go with you, Benedicite!

Speaker: JULIET
Sentence:
Must die to-morrow! O injurious love,
That respites me a life, whose very comfort
Is still a dying horror!

Speaker: Provost
Sentence: 'Tis pity of him.

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
When I would pray and think, I think and pray
To several subjects. Heaven hath my empty words;
Whilst my invention, hearing not my tongue,
Anchors on Isabel

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
Teach her the way.
O heavens!
Why does my blood thus muster to my heart,
Making both it unable for itself,
And dispossessing all my other parts
Of necessary fitness?
So play the foolish throngs with one that swoons;
Come all to help him, and so stop the air
By which he should revive

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: I am come to know your pleasure.

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
That you might know it, would much better please me
Than to demand what 'tis. Your brother cannot live.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: Even so. Heaven keep your honour!

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
Yet may he live awhile; and, it may be,
As long as you or I yet he must die.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: Under your sentence?

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence: Yea.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
When, I beseech you? that in his reprieve,
Longer or shorter, he may be so fitted
That his soul sicken not.

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
Ha! fie, these filthy vices! It were as good
To pardon him that hath from nature stolen
A man already made, as to remit
Their saucy sweetness that do coin heaven's image
In stamps that are forbid

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: 'Tis set down so in heaven, but not in earth.

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
Say you so? then I shall pose you quickly.
Which had you rather, that the most just law
Now took your brother's life; or, to redeem him,
Give up your body to such sweet uncleanness
As she that he hath stain'd?

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
Sir, believe this,
I had rather give my body than my soul.

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence: I talk not of your soul

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: How say you?

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
Nay, I'll not warrant that; for I can speak
Against the thing I say. Answer to this

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
Please you to do't,
I'll take it as a peril to my soul,
It is no sin at all, but charity.

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
Pleased you to do't at peril of your soul,
Were equal poise of sin and charity.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
That I do beg his life, if it be sin,
Heaven let me bear it! you granting of my suit,
If that be sin, I'll make it my morn prayer
To have it added to the faults of mine,
And nothing of your answer.

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
Nay, but hear me.
Your sense pursues not mine

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
Let me be ignorant, and in nothing good,
But graciously to know I am no better.

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
Thus wisdom wishes to appear most bright
When it doth tax itself; as these black masks
Proclaim an enshield beauty ten times louder
Than beauty could, display'd. But mark me;
To be received plain, I'll speak more gross

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: So.

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
And his offence is so, as it appears,
Accountant to the law upon that pain.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: True.

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
Admit no other way to save his life,--
As I subscribe not that, nor any other,
But in the loss of question,--that you, his sister,
Finding yourself desired of such a person,
Whose credit with the judge, or own great place,
Could fetch your brother from the manacles
Of the all-building law; and that there were
No earthly mean to save him, but that either
You must lay down the treasures of your body
To this supposed, or else to let him suffer;
What would you do?

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: As much for my poor brother as myself

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence: Then must your brother die.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: And 'twere the cheaper way

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
Were not you then as cruel as the sentence
That you have slander'd so?

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
Ignomy in ransom and free pardon
Are of two houses

Speaker: ANGELO
ISABELLA
Sentence:
O, pardon me, my lord; it oft falls out,
To have what we would have, we speak not what we mean

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence: We are all frail.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
Else let my brother die,
If not a feodary, but only he
Owe and succeed thy weakness.

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence: Nay, women are frail too.

Speaker: ISABELLA
ANGELO
Sentence: I think it well

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: I have no tongue but one

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence: Plainly conceive, I love you.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
My brother did love Juliet,
And you tell me that he shall die for it.

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence: He shall not, Isabel, if you give me love.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
I know your virtue hath a licence in't,
Which seems a little fouler than it is,
To pluck on others.

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
Believe me, on mine honour,
My words express my purpose.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
Ha! little honour to be much believed,
And most pernicious purpose! Seeming, seeming!
I will proclaim thee, Angelo; look for't

Speaker: ANGELO
Sentence:
Who will believe thee, Isabel?
My unsoil'd name, the austereness of my life,
My vouch against you, and my place i' the state,
Will so your accusation overweigh,
That you shall stifle in your own report
And smell of calumny. I have begun,
And now I give my sensual race the rein

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
To whom should I complain? Did I tell this,
Who would believe me? O perilous mouths,
That bear in them one and the self-same tongue,
Either of condemnation or approof;
Bidding the law make court'sy to their will

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: So then you hope of pardon from Lord Angelo?

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
Be absolute for death; either death or life
Shall thereby be the sweeter. Reason thus with life

Speaker: Provost
Sentence: Who's there? come in

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: Dear sir, ere long I'll visit you again.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: My business is a word or two with Claudio.

Speaker: Provost
Sentence: And very welcome. Look, signior, here's your sister.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: Provost, a word with you.

Speaker: Provost
Sentence: As many as you please.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: Bring me to hear them speak, where I may be concealed.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
Why,
As all comforts are; most good, most good indeed.
Lord Angelo, having affairs to heaven,
Intends you for his swift ambassador,
Where you shall be an everlasting leiger

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
None, but such remedy as, to save a head,
To cleave a heart in twain.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: Yes, brother, you may live

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
Ay, just; perpetual durance, a restraint,
Though all the world's vastidity you had,
To a determined scope.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
In such a one as, you consenting to't,
Would bark your honour from that trunk you bear,
And leave you naked.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
O, I do fear thee, Claudio; and I quake,
Lest thou a feverous life shouldst entertain,
And six or seven winters more respect
Than a perpetual honour. Darest thou die?
The sense of death is most in apprehension;
And the poor beetle, that we tread upon,
In corporal sufferance finds a pang as great
As when a giant dies.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
There spake my brother; there my father's grave
Did utter forth a voice. Yes, thou must die

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
O, 'tis the cunning livery of hell,
The damned'st body to invest and cover
In prenzie guards! Dost thou think, Claudio?
If I would yield him my virginity,
Thou mightst be freed.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
Yes, he would give't thee, from this rank offence,
So to offend him still. This night's the time
That I should do what I abhor to name,
Or else thou diest to-morrow.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
O, were it but my life,
I'ld throw it down for your deliverance
As frankly as a pin.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: Be ready, Claudio, for your death tomorrow.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: Which is the least?

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: What says my brother?

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: And shamed life a hateful.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: Alas, alas!

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
O you beast!
O faithless coward! O dishonest wretch!
Wilt thou be made a man out of my vice?
Is't not a kind of incest, to take life
From thine own sister's shame? What should I think?
Heaven shield my mother play'd my father fair!
For such a warped slip of wilderness
Ne'er issued from his blood. Take my defiance!
Die, perish! Might but my bending down
Reprieve thee from thy fate, it should proceed

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
O, fie, fie, fie!
Thy sin's not accidental, but a trade.
Mercy to thee would prove itself a bawd

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: Vouchsafe a word, young sister, but one word.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: What is your will?

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
Might you dispense with your leisure, I would by and
by have some speech with you

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
I have no superfluous leisure; my stay must be
stolen out of other affairs; but I will attend you awhile.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
Son, I have overheard what hath passed between you
and your sister. Angelo had never the purpose to
corrupt her; only he hath made an essay of her
virtue to practise his judgment with the disposition
of natures

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: Hold you there

Speaker: Provost
Sentence: What's your will, father

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
That now you are come, you will be gone. Leave me
awhile with the maid

Speaker: Provost
Sentence: In good time.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: The hand that hath made you fair hath made you good

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: I am now going to resolve him

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: That shall not be much amiss

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
Let me hear you speak farther. I have spirit to do
anything that appears not foul in the truth of my spirit.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
Virtue is bold, and goodness never fearful. Have
you not heard speak of Mariana, the sister of
Frederick the great soldier who miscarried at sea?

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: I have heard of the lady, and good words went with her name.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
She should this Angelo have married; was affianced
to her by oath, and the nuptial appointed

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: Can this be so? did Angelo so leave her?

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
Left her in her tears, and dried not one of them
with his comfort; swallowed his vows whole,
pretending in her discoveries of dishonour

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
What a merit were it in death to take this poor maid
from the world! What corruption in this life, that
it will let this man live! But how out of this can she avail?

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: It is a rupture that you may easily heal

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: Show me how, good father.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
This forenamed maid hath yet in her the continuance
of her first affection

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
The image of it gives me content already; and I
trust it will grow to a most prosperous perfection.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
It lies much in your holding up. Haste you speedily
to Angelo

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: I thank you for this comfort. Fare you well, good father.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: O heavens! what stuff is here

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
And you, good brother father. What offence hath
this man made you, sir?

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
Fie, sirrah! a bawd, a wicked bawd!
The evil that thou causest to be done,
That is thy means to live. Do thou but think

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
Nay, if the devil have given thee proofs for sin,
Thou wilt prove his. Take him to prison, officer

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
That we were all, as some would seem to be,
From our faults, as faults from seeming, free!

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
How now, noble Pompey! What, at the wheels of
Caesar? art thou led in triumph? What, is there
none of Pygmalion's images, newly made woman, to be
had now, for putting the hand in the pocket and
extracting it clutch'd? What reply, ha? What
sayest thou to this tune, matter and method? Is't
not drowned i' the last rain, ha? What sayest
thou, Trot? Is the world as it was, man? Which is
the way? Is it sad, and few words? or how? The
trick of it?

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: Still thus, and thus; still worse!

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
How doth my dear morsel, thy mistress? Procures she
still, ha?

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
Why, 'tis good; it is the right of it; it must be
so

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence: Why, 'tis not amiss, Pompey. Farewell

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence: Well, then, imprison him

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
No, indeed, will I not, Pompey; it is not the wear.
I will pray, Pompey, to increase your bondage

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: And you.

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence: Does Bridget paint still, Pompey, ha?

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
Then, Pompey, nor now. What news abroad, friar?
what news?

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
Go to kennel, Pompey; go.
What news, friar, of the duke?

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: I know none. Can you tell me of any?

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
Some say he is with the Emperor of Russia; other
some, he is in Rome

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: I know not where; but wheresoever, I wish him well.

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
It was a mad fantastical trick of him to steal from
the state, and usurp the beggary he was never born
to. Lord Angelo dukes it well in his absence; he
puts transgression to 't.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: He does well in 't.

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
A little more lenity to lechery would do no harm in
him

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: It is too general a vice, and severity must cure it.

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
Yes, in good sooth, the vice is of a great kindred;
it is well allied

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: How should he be made, then?

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
Some report a sea-maid spawned him; some, that he
was begot between two stock-fishes. But it is
certain that when he makes water his urine is
congealed ice; that I know to be true

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: You are pleasant, sir, and speak apace.

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
Why, what a ruthless thing is this in him, for the
rebellion of a codpiece to take away the life of a
man! Would the duke that is absent have done this?
Ere he would have hanged a man for the getting a
hundred bastards, he would have paid for the nursing
a thousand

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
I never heard the absent duke much detected for
women; he was not inclined that way.

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence: O, sir, you are deceived.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: 'Tis not possible.

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
Who, not the duke? yes, your beggar of fifty; and
his use was to put a ducat in her clack-dish

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: You do him wrong, surely.

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
Sir, I was an inward of his. A shy fellow was the
duke

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: What, I prithee, might be the cause?

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
No, pardon; 'tis a secret must be locked within the
teeth and the lips

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: Wise! why, no question but he was.

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence: A very superficial, ignorant, unweighing fellow.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: Either this is the envy in you, folly, or mistaking

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence: Sir, I know him, and I love him.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
Love talks with better knowledge, and knowledge with
dearer love.

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence: Come, sir, I know what I know.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
I can hardly believe that, since you know not what
you speak. But, if ever the duke return, as our
prayers are he may, let me desire you to make your
answer before him. If it be honest you have spoke,
you have courage to maintain it

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence: Sir, my name is Lucio; well known to the duke.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
He shall know you better, sir, if I may live to
report you.

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence: I fear you not.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
O, you hope the duke will return no more; or you
imagine me too unhurtful an opposite. But indeed I
can do you little harm; you'll forswear this again.

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence: I'll be hanged first

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: Why should he die, sir?

Speaker: LUCIO
Sentence:
Why? For filling a bottle with a tundish. I would
the duke we talk of were returned again

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
No might nor greatness in mortality
Can censure 'scape; back-wounding calumny
The whitest virtue strikes. What king so strong
Can tie the gall up in the slanderous tongue?
But who comes here?

Speaker: ESCALUS
Sentence: Go; away with her to prison!

Speaker: ESCALUS
Sentence:
Double and treble admonition, and still forfeit in
the same kind! This would make mercy swear and play
the tyrant.

Speaker: Provost
Sentence:
A bawd of eleven years' continuance, may it please
your honour.

Speaker: ESCALUS
Sentence: That fellow is a fellow of much licence

Speaker: Provost
Sentence:
So please you, this friar hath been with him, and
advised him for the entertainment of death.

Speaker: ESCALUS
Sentence: Good even, good father.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: Bliss and goodness on you!

Speaker: ESCALUS
Sentence: Of whence are you?

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
Not of this country, though my chance is now
To use it for my time

Speaker: ESCALUS
Sentence: What news abroad i' the world?

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
None, but that there is so great a fever on
goodness, that the dissolution of it must cure it

Speaker: ESCALUS
Sentence:
One that, above all other strifes, contended
especially to know himself.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: What pleasure was he given to?

Speaker: ESCALUS
Sentence:
Rather rejoicing to see another merry, than merry at
any thing which professed to make him rejoice

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
He professes to have received no sinister measure
from his judge, but most willingly humbles himself
to the determination of justice

Speaker: ESCALUS
Sentence:
You have paid the heavens your function, and the
prisoner the very debt of your calling. I have
laboured for the poor gentleman to the extremest
shore of my modesty

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
If his own life answer the straitness of his
proceeding, it shall become him well; wherein if he
chance to fail, he hath sentenced himself.

Speaker: ESCALUS
Sentence: I am going to visit the prisoner. Fare you well.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
Peace be with you!
He who the sword of heaven will bear
Should be as holy as severe;
Pattern in himself to know,
Grace to stand, and virtue go;
More nor less to others paying
Than by self-offences weighing.
Shame to him whose cruel striking
Kills for faults of his own liking!
Twice treble shame on Angelo,
To weed my vice and let his grow!
O, what may man within him hide,
Though angel on the outward side!
How may likeness made in crimes,
Making practise on the times,
To draw with idle spiders' strings
Most ponderous and substantial things!
Craft against vice I must apply

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
'Tis good; though music oft hath such a charm
To make bad good, and good provoke to harm.
I pray, you, tell me, hath any body inquired
for me here to-day? much upon this time have
I promised here to meet.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
I do constantly believe you. The time is come even
now. I shall crave your forbearance a little

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
Very well met, and well come.
What is the news from this good deputy?

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
He hath a garden circummured with brick,
Whose western side is with a vineyard back'd;
And to that vineyard is a planched gate,
That makes his opening with this bigger key

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: But shall you on your knowledge find this way?

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: I have ta'en a due and wary note upon't

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
Are there no other tokens
Between you 'greed concerning her observance?

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
No, none, but only a repair i' the dark;
And that I have possess'd him my most stay
Can be but brief; for I have made him know
I have a servant comes with me along,
That stays upon me, whose persuasion is
I come about my brother.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
'Tis well borne up.
I have not yet made known to Mariana
A word of this. What, ho! within! come forth!
I pray you, be acquainted with this maid;
She comes to do you good.

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence: I do desire the like.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence: Do you persuade yourself that I respect you?

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
Take, then, this your companion by the hand,
Who hath a story ready for your ear.
I shall attend your leisure

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
O place and greatness! millions of false eyes

Speaker: ISABELLA
Sentence:
She'll take the enterprise upon her, father,
If you advise it.

Speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
Sentence:
It is not my consent,

We do instate and widow you withal,
